summary: This is an email from the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York, dated July 8, 2019, summarizing a New York Times article about the unsealing of a sex trafficking indictment against Jeffrey Epstein. It details the seizure of nude photos from his mansion, the new charges, and criticizes the 2008 non-prosecution agreement overseen by Alexander Acosta.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The central figure accused of sex trafficking and exploiting dozens of underage girls from 2002 to 2005. The document details the new indictment, the seizure of evidence from his homes, and his 2008 plea deal.

persons.name: Geoffrey S. Berman
persons.context: The federal prosecutor who announced the new indictment, stated the victims deserve their day in court, and explicitly stated his office was not bound by the 2008 Florida non-prosecution agreement.

persons.name: Alexander Acosta
persons.role: Former U.S. Attorney in Miami, then Secretary of Labor
persons.context: Identified as the federal prosecutor who oversaw the 2008 non-prosecution agreement with Epstein that allowed him to avoid federal charges.

persons.name: Bill Clinton
persons.context: Mentioned as part of Epstein's high-profile social circle.

persons.name: Prince Andrew
persons.context: Mentioned as part of Epstein's high-profile social circle.

persons.name: Donald Trump
persons.context: Quoted from a 2002 New York Magazine article describing Epstein as 'a terrific guy' and 'a lot of fun to be with'.

events.title: FBI/NYPD Raid on Epstein's Mansion
events.description: FBI agents and NYPD officers used a crowbar to force open the doors of Jeffrey Epstein's East 71st Street mansion in Manhattan.

events.title: Indictment Unsealed in Manhattan
events.description: Federal prosecutors unsealed an indictment charging Jeffrey Epstein with sex trafficking and conspiracy, based on a new investigation. Prosecutors revealed nude photos of underage girls were seized from his home.

events.title: Florida Non-Prosecution Agreement
events.description: Federal prosecutors in Miami, overseen by Alexander Acosta, entered a deal with Epstein allowing him to plead guilty to state prostitution charges and avoid federal prosecution and a possible life sentence.

events.title: Alleged Sex Trafficking Scheme
events.description: The indictment alleges Epstein and his employees engaged in a sex trafficking scheme, bringing underage girls to his homes in New York and Palm Beach for sex acts.

events.title: Initial Florida Investigation
events.description: Law enforcement in Florida investigated Epstein after parents of an accuser reported an incident to police.

events.title: Federal Judge Rules Against 2008 Deal
events.description: A federal judge ruled that prosecutors violated the law by not consulting Epstein's accusers about the 2008 plea deal before finalizing it.

events.title: DOJ Probe into 2008 Deal
events.description: The Justice Department opened a probe into the handling of the 2008 non-prosecution agreement.

keyFacts: Investigators seized nude photographs of underage girls from Jeffrey Epstein's Manhattan townhouse as part of the new investigation leading to the 2019 indictment.
The 2019 indictment charges Epstein with sex trafficking and conspiracy, alleging he exploited dozens of minors, some as young as 14, from 2002 to 2005 in New York and Florida.

The document highlights the 2008 non-prosecution agreement overseen by then-U.S. Attorney Alexander Acosta as a controversial deal that allowed Epstein to avoid federal prosecution, which the Southern District of New York explicitly stated it was not bound by.
A federal judge ruled in early 2019 that prosecutors violated the law by not informing Epstein's accusers about the 2008 plea deal before it was finalized.
The document notes Epstein's high-profile social connections, including former President Bill Clinton, Prince Andrew, and Donald Trump, who praised him in a 2002 interview.
